key_points: U.S. Sen. Pat Toomey of Pennsylvania is facing anger from state Republican Party committee members over his vote to convict Donald Trump during the former president's second impeachment trial.
A censure vote against Toomey is being considered, although it is symbolic since Toomey is not seeking reelection.
Toomey calls for Republicans to be tolerant of differing opinions regarding Trump's role in the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.
Toomey was one of seven Republicans who voted to convict Trump of "incitement of insurrection".
The state GOP chair, Lawrence Tabas, is planning a meeting to discuss a potential censure resolution against Toomey.
Toomey supporters are pushing back against the censure, arguing that a "Trump litmus test" for loyalty is divisive and damaging.
Toomey argued against turning a blind eye when a president attempts illegal and unconstitutional means of staying in power.
Once a champion for conservative challenges within the GOP, Toomey has become criticized by Trump loyalists for his objections to Trump's conduct.
Despite backing many of Trump's policies, Toomey's reluctance to closely align with Trump has made him a target within his party.
"The fact pattern," Toomey said, "I think is pretty damning."
spokespersons: Jezree Friend (State Committee Member, Erie County)
Sam DeMarco (Chair, Allegheny County Republican Party)
